edge: La La Land is a musical romantic comedy-drama film written and directed by Damien Chazelle.
Damien Chazelle first conceptualized the film alongside Justin Hurwitz while attending Harvard University together.
La La Land is a musical romantic comedy-drama film written and directed by Damien Chazelle.
La La Land stars Ryan Gosling as a struggling jazz pianist and an aspiring actress who meet and fall in love while pursuing their dreams in Los Angeles.
La La Land stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone as a struggling jazz pianist and an aspiring actress who meet and fall in love while pursuing their dreams in Los Angeles.
The supporting cast includes John Legend, Rosemarie DeWitt, Finn Wittrock, and J. K. Simmons.

Chazelle, as a drummer, has a predilection for musical films.
As a writer, Chazelle wrote the screenplay for La La Land in 2010 when the film industry seemed out of reach for him.
Chazelle, as a student at Harvard University, conceived the idea for La La Land with his classmate Justin Hurwitz.
After graduating, both Chazelle and Hurwitz moved to Los Angeles in 2010 and continued writing the script for La La Land, altering the location from Boston to Los Angeles.

node_1: guy and madeline on a park bench
edge: Chazelle and Hurwitz explored the concept for La La Land in their senior thesis through a low-budget musical about a Boston jazz musician called Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench.
Chazelle wanted to take the old musical but ground it in real life where things don't always exactly work out.
Chazelle conceived La La Land as a salute to creative people who move to Los Angeles to chase their dreams.
Rather than trying to match L.A. To the charms of Paris or San Francisco, he focused on the qualities that make the city distinctive: the traffic, the sprawl, and the skylines.
The film also makes visual allusions to Hollywood classics such as Broadway Melody of 1940, Singin' in the Rain, The Band Wagon, and An American in Paris.
About An American in Paris, Chazelle commented: 'That's a movie that we just pillaged. It's an awesome example of how daring some of those old musicals really were.'
La La Land in particular is inspired by his experience of moving from the East Coast with preconceived notions of what L.A. Would be like, 'that it was all just strip malls and freeways'.
He said that both films reflect his own experiences as a filmmaker working his way up the Hollywood ladder.
Chazelle said: 'Both films reflect my own experiences as a filmmaker working his way up the Hollywood ladder'.

node_2: style and tone of the film were inspired by
edge: The style and tone of the film were inspired by Jacques Demy's The Umbrellas of Cherbourg and The Young Girls of Rochefort, especially the latter, which was more dance and jazz-oriented.
The Hollywood Reporter called jazz musical an 'extinct genre'.
Chazelle wrote Sebastian's character trait as a reflection of his own relationship with the past and with jazz, too.
Chazelle was unable to produce the film for years as no studio was willing to finance an original contemporary musical with no familiar songs.

Chazelle later wrote Whiplash, which was an easier concept to sell and a less risky investment. After Whiplash was well received by critics upon its premiere at the 2014 Sundance Film Festival in January, Chazelle continued his efforts to bring La La Land to the big screen. Five years after Chazelle wrote the script for La La Land, Summit Entertainment and Black Label Media, along with producer Marc Platt, agreed to invest in La La Land and distribute it since they were impressed by the critical and commercial success of Whiplash.

When Whiplash earned five Oscar nominations at the 87th Academy Awards, including Best Picture, and grossed nearly $50 million worldwide off a $3.3 million production budget, Chazelle and his project began to attract attention from studios.
Teller exited via long contract negotiations, implying a decision-making process involving communication between the actor and director.

At the 89th Academy Awards, La La Land received a leading six awards, namely Best Director, Best Actress (for Stone), Best Cinematography, Best Original Score, Best Original Song ("City of Stars"), and Best Production Design.[123] Its other nominations were Best Picture, Best Actor (for Gosling), Best Original Screenplay, Best Film Editing, Best Costume Design, a second nomination for Best Original Song ("Audition (The Fools Who Dream)"), Best Sound Editing, and Best Sound Mixing.[125] During the Oscars ceremony, presenter Faye Dunaway incorrectly announced that La La Land had won Best Picture, reading from the card Warren Beatty opened, which was actually a duplicate of the Best Actress card for Emma Stone.[126]

At the 89th Academy Awards, La La Land received a leading six awards, namely Best Director, Best Actress (for Stone), Best Cinematography, Best Original Score, Best Original Song ("City of Stars"), and Best Production Design.[123] The film received a total of 14 nominations, tying the record for most nominations by a single film with All About Eve (1950) and Titanic (1997).[124] Its other nominations were Best Picture, Best Actor (for Gosling), Best Original Screenplay, Best Film Editing, Best Costume Design, a second nomination for Best Original Song ("Audition (The Fools Who Dream)"), Best Sound Editing, and Best Sound Mixing.[125] During the Oscars ceremony, presenter Faye Dunaway incorrectly announced that La La Land had won Best Picture, reading from the card Warren Beatty opened, which was actually a duplicate of the Best Actress card for Emma Stone.[126]

In March 2017, German comedians arranged for a Ryan Gosling impersonator to be awarded the 'Best International Film' prize for La La Land at the annual German film and television award, Goldene Kamera. This incident, known as 'GoslingGate', sparked criticism of the event's concept.

In March 2017, German comedians arranged for a Ryan Gosling impersonator to be awarded the 'Best International Film' prize for La La Land at the annual German film and television award, Goldene Kamera. The speaker for television broadcaster ZDF asked for the trophy to be given back, stating that La La Land had won the prize and that the trophy would be given to the real Ryan Gosling.

In March 2017, German comedians arranged for a Ryan Gosling impersonator to be awarded the 'Best International Film' prize for La La Land at the annual German film and television award, Goldene Kamera.
The incident involving 'GoslingGate' played a major role in the cancellation of the Goldene Kamera in 2019.
Media critics argued that the 'Best International Film' award had only been created in an effort to get Ryan Gosling on the show, with no regards for the film's quality.

German comedians Joko Winterscheidt and Klaas Heufer-Umlauf arranged for a Ryan Gosling impersonator to be awarded the 'Best International Film' prize for La La Land at the annual German film and television award, Goldene Kamera.
In 2018, Joko Winterscheidt and Klaas Heufer-Umlauf were awarded the Grimme Award for their media criticism.
On February 7, 2023, it was announced that the film would be adapted into a Broadway musical by Platt and Lionsgate.
The speaker for television broadcaster ZDF asked for the trophy to be given back, stating that La La Land had won the prize and that the trophy would be given to the real Ryan Gosling.
Hurwitz, Pasek & Paul will return to write additional songs for the Broadway musical adaptation of La La Land.
A theatrical spin-off, So Long Boulder City, was created in 2017 by comedians Jimmy Fowlie and Jordan Black. The show was a full-length parody of Mia Dolan's one-woman show from the movie.
In So Long Boulder City, comedian Jimmy Fowlie portrays Mia Dolan in drag.
Comedians Jimmy Fowlie and Jordan Black created a theatrical spin-off, So Long Boulder City, in 2017.

After debuting in Los Angeles, the parody show So Long Boulder City enjoyed a run at the SubCulture Off-Broadway theater in New York City.
